thesis.description: During recent years tbe increasing economic importance of the mosaic and other virus diseases of our crop plants has given a great impetus to the study of these obscure troubles. As a result, the known mosaics have been increased £rom the single one affecting tobacco to numerous mosaics of other Solanaceae, Leguminoseae and Gramineae, with scattered cases in twenty or more additional families of both Monoctotyledons end Dicotyledons. Current literature is replete with reports of mosaic diseases on new plants, either wild or cultivated, and studies concerning plant virus diseases are daily entering widely divergent channels of research. [...]
thesis.creator: Boothroyd, Raymond Atkinson.
thesis.subject: Plant Pathology.
thesis.title: Studies concerning mosaic diseases of plants.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The investigation to be described deals with the measurement of the vapour pressures and conductivities of the three component system calcium oxide - water - sulphur dioxide, and incidentally of the two component system calcium oxide - water. The investigation covers a large range of variations in temperature and in concentration. The above is a concise statement of the experimental side of the problem. The development of new experimental technique for making these measurements had, of course, a theoretical objective, viz. an elucidation of the equilibria existing in these systems, especially as there is an intensely practical side to this elucidation. To make this clear it is necessary to elaborate on previous investigations undertaken in this laboratory which culminated in the work to be described. [...]
thesis.creator: Gurd, George W.
thesis.subject: Chemistry.
thesis.title: Equilibria in the three-component system Calcium oxide - sulphur dioxide - water over the temperature range 22c to 130c.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The phenomenon of polymerization has attracted considerable scientific attention during recent years. This activity is due to the fact that many naturally-occurring materials, important from both the scientific and industrial standpoints, such as cellulose, starch and other complex polysaccharides, resins, rubber and proteins, have been shown to be products whose properties were similar, if not identical, with those of highly polymerized compounds produced in the laboratory. [...]
thesis.creator: Allen, John Stanley.
thesis.subject: Polymers.
Chemistry, Organic.
Chemistry.
thesis.title: Nature of polymerization and its relation to the dielectric constant : and The electric moment in relation to the structure of organic compounds.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: A kinetic study of the oxidation of gaseous acetaldehyde by means of molecular oxygen is of interest for two reasons: 1} because it leads to a mechanism for the oxidation which differs in part from those already proposed for the auto-oxidation of acetaldehyde, this mechanism being in line with one of the several theories of oxidation; 2) because the kinetic chacteristics of this reaction compare in an interesting manner with those found in the auto-oxidation of other organic compounds. [...]
thesis.creator: Howland, Frances.
thesis.subject: Chemistry.
thesis.title: The mechanism of organic reactions in the gaseous state: the kinetics of the oxidation of gaseous acetaldehyde.

thesis.description: A study of the economic and commercial aspects of aviation in Canada involves practically the entire field of civil flying in this country and its position in the national economy.The aspects of aviation which may be more strictly classed as "economic and commercial" have naturally been given the most lengthy treatment in this thesis but a brief consideration of certain other aspects at appropriate points is essential to a proper understanding of the major features. [...]
thesis.creator: Nelles, James Gordon.
thesis.subject: Economics.
thesis.title: The economic and commercial aspects of aviation in Canada.

thesis.description: In 1929 the American Geographic Society undertook the planning and financing of a research programme which included a socio-economic study of the Canadian Prairie Provinces. A research body, the Canadian Pioneer Problems Committee, whose members are on the Staffs of Canadian Universities, was formed for the express purpose of directing the Canadian part of the programme. A five-year project is under way and it includes a survey of social and economic conditions in selected areas of the Prairie Provinces. The survey is a direct outcome of a growing body of opinion that foundations ought to be laid for a science of settlement. Plans are under way for similar research projects to be carried on in the fringes of land settlment in other parts of the world, such as the far western prairie regions of United States, Alaska, South America, South Africa, Australia, and Manchuria. [...]
thesis.creator: Younge, Eva R.
thesis.subject: Sociology.
Peace River District (B.C. and Alta.) -- Social conditions.
Prairie Provinces -- Social conditions.
thesis.title: Social organization on the pioneer fringe with special reference to the Peace River area.

thesis.description: "Wine is the living blood of the grape".(1) It is the suitably fermented juice of freshly gathered grapes. There is no such thing as unfermented wine, even if the word "wine" issometimes used in connection with other fruits to denote a beverage which has fermented. There is a great deal of water in the juice of grapes - about 80% or more of its tota1 weight, p1us anything between 10 and 15% of grape-sugar, which, when duly fermented gives between 10 and 15% alcohol. [...]
thesis.creator: Weissenburger, Pierre Charles.
thesis.subject: Wine industry -- Canada.

thesis.title: Wine in Canada : a study of the economic, fiscal and legislative aspects of the production and sale of wine in Canada.

thesis.description: The successful application of the use of cyanide solutions for the extraction of gold and silver from their ores, may be said to date from the MacArthur and Forrest patent of 1888. Since that date it has become by far the most important method of extracting gold. While, however, many investigations have been made on the reactions that occur, most of these researches were made in the early days and much of the later work has been devoted solely to mechanical improvements in the process. [...]
thesis.creator: Westwood, Robert James.
thesis.subject: Engineering.
thesis.title: An investigation into the chemical reactions that occur during the cyanidation of gold ores.

thesis.description: This work began as a further study of the effect of temperature on stomatal movement as commenced by Scarth and Brown (unpub.). As temperature effects cannot be studied alone, the other environmental factors were taken into account, especially turgidity of leaf and factors governing night opening of stomata and, as it turned out, the most important result of the investigation concerns the latter. thesis.description: The pldgeon-hole type of mind performs and reports research in independent units. Each chapter below may be regarded by some as a pldgeon-hole, as an entity in that small fieldit prescribes for itself. However, there are numerous relations between these filing divisions which must be stressed: The results from one division suggested the field for the next division. Certain of the dovecote boxes were left half filled if further work would not advance the general alkali cellulose (particularly wood cellulose) research program, or if the theories engedering them proved not sound. thesis.description: By the terms of the British North America Act of 1867 each of the Provinces of Canada was given the control of education within its own boundaries. Quebec, in common with the other eight provinces, proceeded to develop a system conformable to its requirements. Because of unusual circumstances, the Quebec system differs materially from all others in Canada. The majority of the population in Quebec is French and Catholic. The French naturally wished to retain their own language and 1ndividua1ity; the Catholic church insisted that there should be religious instruction in the schools. There was a large English minority in the province, however, who wished its children educated in English and the instruction to be free from the Catholic bias. [...]
thesis.creator: Steeves, Reginald.
thesis.subject: Junior high schools.
Education, Secondary -- Québec (Province) -- Montréal.
Education.
thesis.title: The junior high school : with particular reference to Montreal.

thesis.description: It is surprising that relatively little attention has been paid to the elastic elements in the numerous histological investigations of the normal and pathological human heart. The reasons may well be that, in the first place, the old anatomists and physiologists were naturally interested in studying the histology of the elements of so active an organ,and, secondly, specific staining methods were comparatively undeveloped and therefore were relatively unreliable. Still, it is interesting to note that Langhans quite accurately stated, as early as 1866, that the new tissue in the intima in arteriosclerosis consisted largely of elastic fibres. A brief historical review (26) will support these statements. [...]
thesis.creator: Spector, Leo Lyon.
thesis.subject: Myocardium -- Diseases.
Pathology.
Heart -- Aging.
thesis.title: The elastic fibres of the heart muscle in various age periods and in disease.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

By isolating the intermediate products the authors were able to trace the reaction from the primary aldol condensation to the ultimate cyclopentenone ring; the reaction is represented as follows. thesis.description: The Nebaliacea are small white to transparent crustaceans of geologically ancient lineage and morphologically generalized type, remotely related to the fresh-water "fairy shrimps" or Phyllopoda, and they might be called "marine fairy shrimps". They are collectively equivalent to the other great orders of the class Crustacea, but are represented only by about a dozen existing named species and local races. In outward appearance they bear some resemblance to an overgrown Cyclops-like copepod, varying in length from about one-third of an inch to one inch. [...]
thesis.creator: Clark, Annie Elizabeth.
thesis.subject: Zoology.
Leptostraca.
Oysters -- Reproduction.
Spermatozoa.
thesis.title: Nebaliella Cabot n. sp. with observations on other Nabaliacea - The effects of temperature and salinity on the spermatozoa, ova, and development to the first swimming of Ostrea virginica - Variations in numbers of oyster larvae in correlation with temperature and salinity.

thesis.description: Of course the tendency towards the federation of small states into larger units is as old as history itself. In ancient Greece the Amphictyonic Leagues, associations of neighbouring tribes or cities were formed for mutual intercourse or to protect some sanctuary like that at Delphi. In their peace pact the members pledged themsel ves "We will not destroy anycity of the Amphictyons nor cut off the supply of running water, either in war or peace and if any menber break this oath we will make war upon him and destroy his cities". l Again, in the Etruscan cities, the Lucumo leaders of priestly character, elected for life by the people and wielding power superior even to that of the king, met together at frequent intervals to discuss matters of common interest. [...]
thesis.creator: Challies, George Swan.
thesis.subject: Economics.
thesis.title: The United States of Europe.

thesis.description: The intrapleural pressure is generally regarded as merely an observation made during the course of pneumothorax therapy. It is true that on this continent scattered observations on the intrapleural pressure in various pathological conditions have bean made, but it does not seem to have bean realized that certain foreign investigators have subjected the elastic properties of the lung to a very careful analysis and that this measurement should have graduated from an empirical observation to something of real physiological significance. [...]

thesis.subject: Experimental Medicine.
thesis.title: MEASUREMENT OF THE INTRAPLEURAL PRESSURE IN MAN AND ITS SIGNIFICANCE.

thesis.description: In recent years there have come into existence a large number at scientific subjects whose sole literature is contained in periodicals. They are not sufficiently developed to have beoome the subjects or text-books or even to have become included in texts on related topics. The problem of electron oscillations occupies this category. At most it has claimed half a dozen paragraphs in the most modern writings on Radio Communication. [...]

thesis.title: Electron oscillations in thermionic vacuum tubes.

thesis.description: This thesis is part of a more extended study of the life of John Neilson which I hope to complete later for the degree of Ph.D. It is restricted to the period 1818-1828 and deals with Ne11son's activities in the Assembly of Lower Canada and his representations in England in 1822, on the matter of the Union Bill, and in 1828 before the Canada Committee. Its scope has been further limited to those issues arising out of the constitution, organization and functioning of the government. This involves the question of administration and the struggle between Assembly and Executive for its control, as well as relations with the mother country and with Upper Canada. The closely related fields of law, land settlementand education have not been included. The object has been to bring out Neilson's views on these questions in the belief that they contribute to an understanding of the period. [...]
thesis.creator: Bateson, Nora.
thesis.subject: Neilson, John, 1776-1848.
Canada -- Politics and government -- 1791-1841.
Canada -- History -- 1791-1841.
History.
Constitutional history -- Canada.
thesis.title: John Neilson of Lower Canada (1818-1828).

thesis.description: The records of the National Park Branch, Department of Interior of Canada, show that ruminants in Wainwright Park, Alberta have been parasitized by liver flukes for some years. In 1931 an examination of these records revealed that the infested animals were becoming more numerous and an investigation became desirable. At that time it was uncertain whether the parasites present were of one species, Fascioloides magna, which had been reported from that district in 1923 or were F. magna and Fasciola hepatica. [...]
thesis.creator: Swales, William Eardley.
thesis.subject: Parasitology.
thesis.title: The life cycle of Fascioloides magna (Bassi, 1875; Ward, 1917) in Canada.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The catalytic hydrogenation of oils in the preparation of solid fats for edible and general industrial purposes has been in general use for a comparatively short time. In a broad sense, much is already known about the mechanism and peculiarities of hydrogenation, and process control is largely scientific, there is not, however, sufficient available information covering any one phase of the extensive field of hydrogenation. In view of this fact, it was decided to investigate some of the fundamental aspects of catalytic hydrogenation. With this object in mind, the work to be discussed in the following pages was undertaken. [...]
thesis.creator: Bennett, Robert Douglas.
thesis.subject: Chemistry.
thesis.title: The rate of hydrogenation of certain oils.

thesis.description: In view of the fact that several workers in this field have failed to agree upon the presence of a specific sugar, it has been the aim of this investigation to ascertain, if possible, the presence and quantity of a definite sugar. During the course of the work several other substances have been isolated, identified and studied. The inquiry has beencarried out in conjunction with the Veterinary Department at Macdonald College. thesis.description: The great increase during the last few years in the volume of data available on reaction rates in gaseous systems has resulted in wide extensions in their theoretical treatment and it is now possible to give a satisfactory qualitative explanation for almost all of the results which have been obtained in that field. On the quantitative side progress has not been so marked, the calculation of reaction rates from the properties of the reactant substances apparently having been considered somewhat too hopeless a task to be attempted. [...]

thesis.description: Though the study ot catalytic reactions has long been a subject of great importance and wide investigation, any single definition or a catalytic reaction involves a great deal of controversy. Ostwald has compared a catalyst to a lubricant - a substance, which, though itself unchanged, aids the process, increasing the velocity, but not banging the final position of thermodynamic equilibrium. thesis.description: The internal photoelectric current in rocksalt crystals previously irradiated with ß and Y rays has been studied. The observed decrease of the current with time has been shown to be due to the growth of a back voltage in the crystal. In these crystals a reverse current flows when the crystal is illuminated, without an external field, shortly after the passageof a photocurrent. This reverse current has been shown to be an ordinary photoelectric current due to the back voltage. [...]
thesis.creator: Hurst, Donald Geoffrey.
thesis.subject: Physics.
thesis.title: Photoelectric currents in irradiated rocksalt crystals.
